context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What I understood you to say a little while ago is that what Congress granted in 1953 carried only up to the three-mile limit with some exceptions.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, what was the exception?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That we suppose that there might be a different situation with reference to different states, and the equal footing clause, therefore, though applicable as a matter of constitutional law, might be differently treated by Acts of Congress within its power, as Justice Black said, to deploy the property.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, then, what if -- is the equal footing determinative, by itself, of all the right of the State bordering on the sea?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Go on.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: I thought that was --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's Mr. Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I thought his question was we should take judicial notice of the fact that they couldn't have issued.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: They can't prove it.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: It can have less and this Court recognized the State could extend for a lesser distance than the United States --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But you tried to --

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: -- in U.S.against California.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But you've answered Justice Black, unless that's what ended into his question of your answer that if Congress can explicitly give the Tideland Possession Act, although we ourselves claimed no right to drill for oil beyond the three-mile limit, nothing in this Act shall preclude Louisiana from doing this.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It would have a very different policy.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Well, I agree that that's entirely -- that's a different case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I -- I follow you.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I just --

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That these various --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's the fact you gave to us in your answer to Mr. Justice Black, namely, whether what you call very clear is very clear.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If Congress had said what you have said, there wouldn't be a problem except, if Congress had said, I don't see why a Court within its jurisdiction doesn't allow Louisiana to make a geographic demonstration.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's entirely a judicial purpose about it, interesting as though it might be.

context.speaker: Charles K. Rice
context.text: Well, there again, that question is not before the Court because he was prosecuted under Section 145 (b).

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I understand he were.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If the position now taken by the Government is correct, then you -- then your answer to Justice Black's question is, he couldn't be prosecuted in the 3616 and he's properly prosecuted by the only section under which he could be prosecuted 145 (b).

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is that correct?

context.speaker: Charles K. Rice
context.text: Well, I think that's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Everything fall if that's so, but suppose that isn't so, what then?

context.speaker: Stanley Fleishman

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's the next question I was coming to.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That was the bearing of Justice Harlan's question as I understood it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Stanley Fleishman
context.text: That is included without our -- within our complaint, yes.

context.text: I understood -- I got the impression from what you've said in reply to -- your reply to an earlier question in the series of questions put to you just now by Justice Brennan.

context.text: I got the impression that you said that if damages were sought for, sued apart, that then the defendant in that damage suit could say, "Oh, but what we did wasn't a tort, couldn't be made a tort by state law because it has the statute -- it has the permission of the United States clause.

context.speaker: John D. Mosser
context.text: I think that is correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm not saying that the argument isn't relevant but it doesn't follow.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Richard H. Robinson
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I suppose one difference between the illustration that Justice Harlan's suggested in this should be, that here, not because of any federal constitutional position that wholly a part from it and separately distinct in forgetting one object of this was to convict the man of a crime and the illustration he gives except the one to protect the person and they have a female from a possible contamination in the case of marriage.

context.speaker: Richard H. Robinson
context.text: Well, I agree -- I agree that it's for a different purpose.

context.speaker: Richard H. Robinson
context.text: But in this case, the same evidence though could have been used, had it been a negative test to prove his innocence and in such a statute, I understand such legislation will be hearing this, this time in New Mexico.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: That is a very important difference that there is a speed -- speed and determination of litigation on the habeas corpus which does not generally exist under declaratory judgment.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: And it's always been stressed by this Court going back again to the early cases that with relation to exclusion, with relations to aliens who -- with aliens who are knocking at our gates, Congress wanted speedy summary determination and they didn't want repeated rehearings.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I follow -- I follow on that.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I was not less clear about this -- my own thought whether in your answer to Justice Harlan which indicated a difference in the scope, in the content that in a substantive relieve that can be got in declaratory judgment as against habeas corpus.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: Well, I think I had not completed my answer to that.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: I started out to say that in the early years, the Court said there should be no review of the facts at all.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: There are other very specific provisions which the Court considered in the case of Marcello against Bonds.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: The burden of proof --

To him.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: Because the question of the admissibility of the confession is the question of whether or not it has been obtained in violation of the United States Constitution.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: If there was such a question tied up with the admissibility of the gun, my answer would be the same.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: Admittedly, in some cases, there might be a line to draw but I don't believe this case calls for the drawing of such a line, but clearly, where the only way that a constitutional right can be preserved is by such testimony then its petition is -- contention that the integrity of the whole constitutional defense depends upon this preliminary determination.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, to raise Justice Brennan's question to a constitutional level, suppose this revolver that he's speaking about was -- was to be introduced in evidence and the claim was by the defense that the home had been burglarized, suppose this was a federal case and defendant claim that his home had been burglarized by a federal officer and this -- this gun had been -- been taken and that preliminary -- preliminary question was being tried by the Court.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I presume the defendant could take the stand and testify that -- that he saw the federal officer come -- come in there and burglarize his home without -- without subjecting himself to cross-examination on -- on the guilt or innocence on the charge against him, couldn't he?

context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: -- is a -- is a cognate to related defense.

context.speaker: Earl Warren

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Now, if Section 301 opened a forum in respect of contracts between an incorporated labor organizations and employer.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: And while you're on that Supreme -- Supreme Court of Alabama on which there's nothing about pulling it constitutional and you -- you interpreted as in feasibly holding a constitutional for it is passed on constitutional question itself?

context.speaker: Milton I. Shadur
context.text: Yes, Your -- yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Milton I. Shadur
context.text: That was in the argument to the Alabama Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, the  it's non-concept as Alabama and we know the -- the diversity of the state rulings as the implication of Justice Burton's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: When I read that Alabama Supreme Court opinion, I first thought that all they decided and I'm not still clear that it isn't all they decided.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: We, now telling you're within it.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: That is right and the question as to whether the overt acts which happened within the period of the statutes --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, of course.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: -- are in furtherance of this conspiracy.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: As Justice Harlan indicated, you've got to have an overt act within the period.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: That is right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And you've got to have them related to the conspiracy but not crimes themselves.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: It might make two conspiracies unless the jury on the proper instructions found that it was a -- a single conspiracy.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: If your -- if your argument is correct up to date, it sounds to me like it will be bound to be two.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: But what --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What you think -- if you're saying if you had enough charge in there to support a conspiracy to conceal and to make the -- to defraud the Government by concealing and then it says -- Justice Frankfurter referred to this governmental operation.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Well, if Your Honor pleases.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: And I refer again to the Manton case.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: It would be concealment for all purposes.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan
context.text: Did the judge differentiate it between concealment as to those two purposes to this charge?

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: No -- no, he did not.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, Mr. Davis, I'm -- I'm not quite clear about your answer to Justice Frankfurter and about the -- this next to the last overt act that you -- you spoke of where you said it only -- only applied to a certain number of the defendants, not -- not the rest of them.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, I hope --

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: I didn't mean to say that, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, you may say that's just legal stuff.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But it does, to me, make a difference as the intimation of Justice Clark's in the question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Here is a fellow summoned by a subpoena or he had no choice.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: He didn't take one position one day and another position in another.

Guss v. Utah Labor Relations Board.speaker: Justice Brennan

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, Mr. Attorney General --

context.speaker: E. R. Callister
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Perhaps, I correctly -- did not understand you correctly.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Do you suggest to Mr. Justice Black that if in fact there is consistency between Utah and federal laws, a declination by the Federal Board to act might be viewed as tantamount to a session for the purposes of 10 (a)?

context.speaker: E. R. Callister
context.text: No, no, you misunderstood me.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, that has to be a formal session, does it not?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Why isn't this the course you suggested?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You hate it to suggest probably the right one, it be sent back judgment vacated to let them pass on that question which is certain, encompassed in the general statement "illegally restrained."

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well -- why --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Why don't you answer that before you answered Justice Frankfurter?

context.speaker: J. Ralston Werum
context.text: Well, I would like to -- I think I can answer you, sir.

context.speaker: J. Ralston Werum
context.text: That is you very well put it, if we go back down, no matter whether you send it back down or whether you pass on it as an illegal commitment the alternative is right there.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I can understand why.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Graham.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Graham, would you mind addressing yourself at the moment to the question that Justice Black asked about the feasibility of remanding this -- vacating this -- this decision and remanding it to the Ohio courts to determine the other half of it that might not be here?

context.speaker: James F. Graham
context.text: Not at all, Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Urban P. Van Susteren
context.text: And secondly, if that Article, Article 66 should be so interpreted as to give the Board of Review that authority, then, the Article, in its application to this case, would be contrary tot the ex post facto provisions of the Constitution.

context.speaker: Urban P. Van Susteren
context.text: I would like to take up those arguments in that order.

context.speaker: Urban P. Van Susteren
context.text: First, that they do not have the authority in Article 66.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, before you do that, did I understand you to answer Mr. Justice Frankfurter that you thought there should be a new trial on the merits by new a board of officers?

context.speaker: Urban P. Van Susteren
context.text: A new trial by a whole new court-martial, but I don't feel that we can still have the right to retry the issue of guilt.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Just on the question of sentence?

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: There is no reason why the trial court cannot be affirmed.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: The affidavit is before this Court, the -- all the testimony is before this Court.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: And to me, the -- the proper basis would be to affirm, and I -- another fact for consideration that may be I shouldn't bring up is the fact that petitioner in this case is -- well, I won't settle --

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: But, you would be satisfied if -- if we reverse and remand it to the Court of Appeals to pass upon the admissibility of this affidavit and the other question that Justice Harlan spoke of.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: You haven't -- gotta get attack of -- District Court.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: I would -- I would be satisfied it went back to the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: I would be even more satisfied Your Honor that this Court will affirm the trial court.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I -- may I suggest that the analysis of Justice Harlan, I would agree that whether or not there was a constructive thrust in the state law of question, I suggest that the question of admissibility, a federal law question, In any event, it would -- even so, I wouldn't disagree to it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Assuming you're right, you would have to go back to the federal -- to the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You -- you'd allow your --

context.speaker: John V. Lindsay
context.text: -- I think that this ultimately --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I think you're justifying it, if I may ask you this, you're quite justifying, from my point of view, what you have, in the Hickman case, is a problem of the declaration and you're quite justifying it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I just wonder whether these are comparable to whether the administration of criminal justice is comparable to the kind of consideration that, from my point of view, as you know my concurrence to Justice Jackson for the United States would be there expressed.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I think this is -- I -- I welcome, as you said, this raises far-reaching questions in regard to the administration of criminal justice in the federal courts to find an example, in my point of view, that the Federal Government should set in regard to this case.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you think the judge did remove the cloud here?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And so the rule provide on the basis of what this Court decided that the motion must be made in due time so that that can be disposed of before you get to the trial in order that the trial should not be interrupted.

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: That's right sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And that's what evidently happened here because unless I'm contrary wise informed when the motion was renewed as it has to be renewed at the trial when the Government makes offer.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: There was a quick -- there was no argument about it and that Judge Goodman ruled and dispose of it presumably as Justice Brennan suggest presumably on what had happened in the earlier days.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I mean, it fits quite in with the whole philosophy or the purpose of the rule and the decision, is that right?

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: I -- I think it normally would happen in that way.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The fact that you may search something doesn't mean thereby you can search and seize everything you've searched.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It was a different conception, have different histories and different purposes.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I would like to, if you would argue on a little different basis on what you have.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Assuming -- assuming that this was a reasonable search as Justice Frankfurter has pointed out, it was different.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I haven't heard anything you said, it indicated that you could argue or would argue that it was a reasonable seizure.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Now there are plenty of our cases upheld I suppose -- maybe find -- you find support for your search.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It had to add the fact that the petition was not filed until the cases in the state courts were about to come to file.

context.speaker: Eugene Underwood
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, Mr. Underwood, I -- I'm having some difficulty with your -- with your argument.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: As I understood you, you answered to Mr. Justice Frankfurter that you; under the statute in our decisions, can go in to the District Court and frankly say the value of our ship greatly exceeds the amount of the claims and that you are entitled to -- to be in Court on this proceeding because this Court has recognized the -- your right to have your liability determined in -- in one action.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, that being true, you say that the -- you also said, in answer to my question, that there must not be a lack of good faith.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now what would constitute a lack of good faith in -- in those circumstance -- in -- in filing a suit of that kind if you have that right as I have just outlined it.

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: Well, I suppose that it might -- I might be criticized for the numbers I have picked, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: But I -- I -- (Voice Overlap)

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Yes, but can you -- I'm not neglecting any occurrences at all.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I think Mr. Justice Frankfurter suggested what dominances --

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: I see --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- the proper answer to that but I don't -- I -- I don't understand if this is a matter of law or how you divide up a single claim worth X dollars in that way?

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All they would have --

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What is your answer to Justice Brennan's question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: How -- how do you determine, maybe allocation, how would you allocate the -- the viability for that $100,000 as between the two different owners?

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: Well I -- I would assume, Your Honor, that the District Court would -- in -- in the handling of the fund say that if this fall around the part of both vessels and if there were two proceedings that those -- they should divide it evenly because even under your principles of admiralty law with respect to collision, where you have both to blame, the damages are divided.

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: That's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Mason, does --

context.speaker: Frank C. Mason
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- does this finding of -- or -- or part of the order of Judge Weinfeld quoted in the opinion of the majority in this case answer to Mr. Justice Brennan's question as it appears on page 62 at the top there.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: It said we think, however, Judge Weinfeld's order should be amended to include the following, if claimant obtains a judgment in her state court suit for an amount in excess of $100,000, an injunction will issue permanently enjoining her from collecting such excess unless the judgment rest on a special verdict allocating the amount as between the libellant as owner of the tug and as owner of the barge, respectively.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Thus, if the judgment exceeds $100,000 and the jury finds libellant liable solely as the owner of the tug, she will be enjoined from collecting any excess.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: Now, although there had been no case that's directly in point, there had been several cases, including a case of this Court, which drew light upon the position which I take herein.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: And I will call the Court's attention to several of those cases.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: One --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. McMorris, don't -- don't you think that in response to Justice Harlan's question that it would be better for you to tell how you'd come here to this Court, tell the facts of your case and -- and then after you have done that, why I -- I think you'd be more ready to convince the Court of your position than to live us in the dark until -- until the last of your -- of your argument.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: Well, thank -- thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I -- I think you would --

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: That is right, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: But isn't it true that has to be done only upon application of the accused?

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: I think that is right, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: And if that so, would that not have a bearing on the question raised by Mr. Justice Black, as to the date of the effectiveness of that action?

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: She has to apply and the courts, under no duty to act to vacate the sentence until there is the application.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: May I say this, Mr. Justice Whittaker?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, let me add --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- one more thing.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Although, it applies to special class in the -- if you put on probation, as I understood your answer to Justice Whittaker, you said that automatically the probation agent moves for the lifting of the sentence, but that is not -- that is not a compellable motion so far as the Court is concerned.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May the Court say no in this case, I think.

context.speaker: Samuel Carter McMorris
context.text: I believe --

context.text: Number 72, John M. Lehmann, Petitioner, versus United States of America in relation to Bruno Carson.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Fisher, we might -- I will proceed.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I was waiting for Justice Black but he's delayed a little.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You may proceed.

context.speaker: Roger D. Fisher
context.text: May it please the Court.

Leiter Minerals, Inc., v. United States.case_name: Leiter Minerals, Inc., v. United States

context.speaker: Samuel W. Plauche, Jr.
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Samuel W. Plauche, Jr.
context.text: There was no.

context.speaker: Samuel W. Plauche, Jr.
context.text: That it didn't refer expressly to law that -- that this is what they were doing.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: But -- but it did, as I understand Justice Brennan's question, it -- it did agree that at the end of the 10 years, it should go to the United States.

context.speaker: Samuel W. Plauche, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Samuel W. Plauche, Jr.
context.text: That's -- no.

context.speaker: William J. Smith
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Speaks of experience, ability, character, the manner of performance of previous contracts, financial condition, equipment, any other fact tending to show ability and willingness to conserve the public health and safety and therefore complying with the provisions of this Act.

context.speaker: William J. Smith
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now as to the first -- now perhaps as to all, it's the last two, don't the Government regulations require the inquiry of the contracting officer to be made upon the same standards because looking at page 49 of the Government's brief, the ones that Mr. Justice Clark referred to, financial resources necessary experience and so forth, I think pretty much the same thing.

context.speaker: William J. Smith
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Smith
context.text: Generally speaking, they do.

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: No, sir, as a statement of what the law is, if Your Honor please, I have no quarrel with it.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, what would you suggest should have been Judge Holtzoff's answer to that question?

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: I think his answer in the circumstances here should have been that is a matter which is not properly before you jurors for your consideration and I will not answer that question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You mean -- do I infer from your answer to Justice Brennan that you imply or that you -- you -- we should carry the meaning of what you say that in as much as -- as the amount of the -- in as much as the way in which the judge exercises the discretion other than capital in the sentence that the jury tells particularly.

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: He shouldn't tell him what will influence them because that may influence them in bringing in one sentence rather than another?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Under the jury verdict?

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: Yes, sir, that's -- that's what they asked.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Was an evidence covered by your answer to Justice Whittaker that the jury didn't ask for that?

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: No, I don't mean that.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Then I misunderstood you.

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: They haven't challenged it, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Have they challenged the other question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Have they said, you haven't -- the question that Justice Harlan put that you did not object to the answer by the trial judge?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Did the Government raise that?

context.speaker: William B. Bryant
context.text: Some references made within the Government's brief but not a formal challenge, I believe in the footnote --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Edward L. Barrett, Jr.
context.text: -- exercise of the rulemaking powers.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) forthwith was stricken out.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That forthwith is that you give it to kind of meeting as Justice Brennan said, that means that once you must (Inaudible) into it and there is stuck in there a judgment that's unnecessary mainly in relation to the function.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: May I ask a question before you leave --

context.speaker: Edward L. Barrett, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

Mitchell v. Bekins Van & Storage Company.case_name: Mitchell v. Bekins Van & Storage Company

context.speaker: Bessie Margolin
context.text: Now, they are in a position to get the benefit of taking some of this commercial storage to some of their retail warehouses and we admit that the Act gives them that loophole.

context.speaker: Bessie Margolin
context.text: But when you can't find a warehouse and identify it, it's being like a general merchandise warehouse which is covered.

context.speaker: Bessie Margolin
context.text: Certainly, that is the practical basis for holding that that is a separate establishment.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Would you be kind enough to answer more specifically Justice Burton's question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Suppose you have these warehouses all in one huge modern village --

context.speaker: Bessie Margolin
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William C. Wines
context.text: I wish you would.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- but -- but so far as this argument goes, this isn't the place to determine this.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You can't -- you can't, unless the Supreme Court of Illinois has spoken on this question and except insofar as we do from time to time give a great weight to what the Attorney General of a State says.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You can't answer categorically Justice Brennan's question if that hasn't as a matter of statutory construction and passed on.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What you're telling us now is that as a matter of fact, as a matter of construction of the statute to -- an answer to his question, it would -- it would not be included, isn't that what you're saying?

context.speaker: William C. Wines
context.text: If Your Honor please, I understand --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Suppose the States -- a State -- a State have -- talked about other businesses, suppose the State had gone into the -- establishes a corporation, a state defense resistant and through that corporation (Inaudible) in New Hampshire or South Carolina or suburb states, dispenses this liquor business --

context.speaker: G. Kent Yowell
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- but also allows private enterprise to be in competition with the State.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But as to this private people, it makes very stringent group, the kind that Justice Brennan read a little while ago, qualifications of all the employees, they must have a pristine of absently pure record, not even a traffic violation.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Would that be discrimination because it doesn't make similar regulations or reference to employees in its dispensary corporation?

context.speaker: G. Kent Yowell
context.text: I was -- I was going to suggest that -- that its own dispensary corporation would be regulated by it.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- money order business?

context.speaker: G. Kent Yowell
context.text: -- carry out the law, I don't know, Your Honor.

context.speaker: G. Kent Yowell
context.text: I assume --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Do the employee -- must the employees of the Western Union satisfy this question as to what Justice Brennan referred in the (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: G. Kent Yowell
context.text: No, and there exempts --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But banking transactions have -- are regulated as banking transaction.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: As I understood you, the Western Union isn't regulated as to these fiduciary transaction, it's regulated as a utility?

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: He said -- he said that --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Then he must have rejected the conclusion which you and I under your inference have drawn from this testimony and hear the witnesses, then you're up against --

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: He didn't --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- Justice Whittaker's question.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: May I -- may I point this out, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: The witnesses that Your Honor speaks of were several directors, only one of which who appeared before Judge Mathes, the others, Judge Mathes never had the benefit of seeing these people anymore than Your Honors have (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- Justice Whittaker's question.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: May I -- may I point this out, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: The witnesses that Your Honor speaks of were several directors, only one of which who appeared before Judge Mathes, the others, Judge Mathes never had the benefit of seeing these people anymore than Your Honors have (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, then what's challenging as Justice Whittaker suggested to you a minute ago, you say that the conclusion which he arrived at is unfounded in law because it's unfounded in fact.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: I say it's unfounded in law because it's unfounded in fact but I go on to say further that assuming that it is unfounded in law as well as unfounded in fact and assuming, however, that he have the right to make such findings.

context.speaker: Herman H. Levy
context.text: I say, nevertheless, I come to this point assuming in other words that these directors were all honest men.

context.speaker: Roger D. Fisher
context.text: That's right, whether the -- the merits would again be tried.

context.speaker: Roger D. Fisher
context.text: I take it the issue there, if you should reverse, would be a conclusion of this Court that as a matter of law, you could not say that this army did not have that authority.

context.speaker: Roger D. Fisher
context.text: And that the question was one of fact to be tried out as to whether these particular guerrillas received particular cables from MacArthur to say they could go ahead and take these supplies.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Fisher, before we allow you to merely make the argument, I'd like to ask you so many question arising out of the question -- the answer you gave to Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Did I understand you to say that one of the contention of the Government is that even assuming there is a claim against the United States, show you one side of the question (Inaudible) that there are limitations as to the fund or the procedure by which -- in law against the limited (Inaudible) did you say something like that or what did you say?

context.speaker: Roger D. Fisher
context.text: What -- we would say that if there is a claim, a constitutional claim for taking because of a taking by authorized officers of the United States that we could not limit the recovery to discretion of the military officers.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: The collusion question was -- was explored below and also explored in the Supreme Court, and they held there was no collusion, and then the Court held that there was federal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Another way stating that then Mr. Doyle in your position is that if there's a bona fide, honest refusal on the part of the corporation to bring the action, no matter what the motivation may be, that's suffices doing that to establish diversity.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: Or the purpose of where the corporation should be aligned and then you apply the diversity rule and you either admit it or you don't.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But in the Koster case, Mr. Doyle as you well know this Court speaking from Justice Jackson that this is a proceeding for public and corporate interest against faithless for these frames against faithfulness in the record.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: That's what we have in this case allegedly.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well the, I thought I've already said I don't -- for all I know, you got it overwhelmingly.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: -- come to that right now if I may.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But may I before you do that --

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- pursue Justice Brennan's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: As I read the oral statement of Judge Barnes, to which you called our attention, he refused to decide the question of collusion and therefore the question of realignment of party on the basis of affidavit and deposition.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And he thought that better go to testimony.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: To prove why they didn't bring that all to -- that was independently controlled --

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: But they -- the -- that the burden is on the plaintiff to state in his complaint the facts which entitle him -- or I mean entitle the court to take jurisdiction and he hasn't done that as the Court of Appeals has held.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Did you -- but you answered yes to Justice Harlan's question that that satisfies the rule and by that, that is the (Inaudible) in a word.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is that -- is the plaintiff or the stockholder can file a complaint and say, "On estoppel and company X?"

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: -- requirements they have to give the reason.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: One of the things --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, but you said yes to Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: Yes --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- (Voice Overlap)-- apprehended it.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: Yes, that's what I'm talking about.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: We don't have to go beyond the decisions of this Court.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: They're under the decisions of this Court, Doctor versus Harrington, Koster versus Lumbermens --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But I suggest that Doctor -- as I take it with Justice Whittaker, Doctor and Harrington is an exception to anything.

context.speaker: James E. S. Baker
context.text: Oh, it states it exactly that, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It isn't -- (Voice Overlap) -- very well, as if you please, you can call them the exception.

context.speaker: Louis C. Wyman
context.text: I hope that before a decision is ultimately made in this case that both of the transcripts on the questioning of this witness which appear in full in the transcript and before the Court will be read to get the general sense of the situation that existed.

context.speaker: Louis C. Wyman
context.text: This would be the relationship between the witness and the persons asking the questions.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I don't follow that, Mr. Attorney General.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Didn't you just answer Mr. Justice Douglas that it was unimportant in terms of the issue under the First Amendment, whether the hearing was public or private?

context.speaker: Louis C. Wyman
context.text: I believe, Your Honor, it's unimportant.

context.speaker: Louis C. Wyman
context.text: There are others who have said in law review journals that there is some appointments to be attached to it and I think what they're really talking about is a matter of method as distinct from a general rule, a matter of method as to whether you proceed in public hearing for reasons somewhat unconcerned with, perhaps just investigating and perhaps connected with political activity.

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: Never any discussion with the employer.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, but so far as the picketing --

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- and as Justice Black has developed, the picketing must have had some purpose.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It wasn't a --

context.speaker: David Previant
context.text: Surely, it did.

context.speaker: Leon B. Lamfrom
context.text: That, by its very nature, every right is related to a duty to exercise so as to cause a minimum of harm to another, least of all to an innocent bystander, that the right of freedom of speech may not be considered a part from that of society to maintain order, that when one who seeks freedom -- that one who seeks freedom may not wholly ignore his neighbor's right to it.

context.speaker: Leon B. Lamfrom
context.text: Now, we have had quite a lot of controversy in the labor relations and in the legal actions that flow from them about recognition picketing and organizational picketing.

context.speaker: Leon B. Lamfrom
context.text: Some inquiry from, I think, Mr. Justice Clark --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I think it was Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Leon B. Lamfrom
context.text: Well, it was directed to that point as to whether or not there is a difference between picketing which results from a demand upon the employer to recognize it as a bargaining agent and picketing which is indulged in without any demand or communication between the Union and the employer.

context.speaker: Leon B. Lamfrom
context.text: There has never --it has never seemed to me that there is any difference in that kind of an approach because the objectives, whether it is so-called recognition picketing or so-called organizational picketing, is the same, namely, to achieve a status whereby the Union gets the representation for the employees involved and proceeds along the normal lines of the sequence of Union representation to attempt to get some kind of a collective bargaining contract.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Does the adversity because of diversity under which the Court has obvious jurisdiction, cuts down on the jurisdiction under 301?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Because of adversity no, it does not cut down the jurisdiction under 301 and we buttress our argument upon 301.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But I want to point out that in the Bernhardt case that it was specifically pointed out that the -- that the United States Arbitration Act did not apply because of lack of allegations with respect to commerce within the meaning of the American Arbitration Act that I'm going to discuss at a subsequent point in the argument.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: What we had there was a straight contract of employment, no allegation of commerce; diversity of citizenship, the Court sent them to the law of Vermont in that particular case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, that if the Amalgamated sues an employer and is able to establish diversity, New York Law would have it govern.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Goldberg, let me recall to you for you know -- must know it well that there was an endeavor to write into the Taft-Hartley Act a provision that any breach, any violation of a provision of any collective agreement shall be deemed to be an unfair labor practice.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And Congress explicitly refused to make that unfair labor practice.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And the reason they -- and the reason, Mr. Justice Frankfurter --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I don't think that if you'd have that, then you would have a clear basis.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The reason they refused to do that was that in the same law they had a provision for resort to courts to do the -- precisely the same thing and the -- the Congressional history which we quote in our brief extensively said they made a choice to permit the courts to do it and not the Labor Board.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Norris-LaGuardia Act in section 4 deals with certain type of activities such as peaceful picketing, strikes, et cetera.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Section 7 of the Norris-LaGuardia Act lays down certain procedural requirements.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The procedural requirements are just in apposite to a case of this character.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: As Justice Jackson said in the case similar, it says to hold the Norris-LaGuardia Act apply to this particular situation would be to drive the knife inward.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There are other problems, the United States Arbitration Act, Mr. Chief Justice, but my colleague, Mr. Feller, will be in a position to discuss that in the Goodall case when he argues it.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I thank you very much for this opportunity.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now, under 301 -- before I do that, I would like to take advantage of a brief chart to indicate where we stay under this area throughout the country.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: This is a much litigated and much difficult area as it occurred from the following.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Almost, in fact, I think every circuit with the exception of an opinion in one circuit by two judges where the opinion is the other way in this case, all the circuits First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth and Seventh, not all, but those circuits, assumed that there is jurisdiction under 301 to bring a suit.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Yes.

United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.speaker: Justice Brennan
United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.case_name: United States v. Union Pacific Railroad Company
United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 23, 1957

context.speaker: William W. Clary
context.text: In the case of Missouri, Kansas, and Texas versus Roberts, it was definitely settled that the right of way passed to the railroad at least upon the construction of the road, if not earlier.

context.speaker: William W. Clary
context.text: That's as close as I can answer your question.

context.speaker: William W. Clary
context.text: Although the grant is commonly spoken of by the Courts as a grant in praesenti, upholding grant which became definite upon the location of this line or, if not then, upon the actual construction of the railroad which was completed in --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, all -- all the discussion you've been having with Mr. Justice Reed on the matter of patents is -- is not pertinent at all to the interest you acquired or settled, --

context.speaker: William W. Clary
context.text: I don't --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- alleging and claiming or acquiring it from --

United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.case_name: United States v. Union Pacific Railroad Company
United States v. Union Pacific Railroad.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 23, 1957

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I ask you a question, I hope I'm not pressing too much.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I understood you to say that the relief of this land or apportionment of this land are and may be, by the railroad, put to use for other uses, at least in one part, is that right?

context.speaker: William W. Clary
context.text: In certain portions of the 400-foot step.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And, now, in the Townsend case, which I've know read for the first time and it's been uncommonly short opinion by Mr. Justice White, they might be a little short.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I learned from that, they couldn't -- the railroad could not alienate it because that would be to make a just use of the grant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It may grant its own purpose.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: -- that would be my position.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- that's your position.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: That is right.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: So then the words that Justice Black read from the -- from the Act do become very forceful, don't they?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And in that anything that the Attorney General desires to inquire probably he has a right to do.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: He has the right to inquire about them, yes, but if you're going to convict the man of crime who's not answering, if there was no reason -- if the question was an unreasonable question or if it violated his constitutional rights, he has the right to refuse to answer.

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: If -- if it is -- if it were -- certainly, if -- if this Court should uphold Judge Sullivan on the ground that only questions with respect to availability were -- were properly asked, I would assume that was an interpretation by this Court if that was the purpose of supervision and that the entire supervision would be --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: John F . Davis
context.text: -- limited to availability.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But Justice Black assumes that we disagree with Judge --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Suppose we do agree with him.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- Judge Sullivan and you've already answered that.

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: It wouldn't have been all right to two strangers?

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, so that the question comes -- to the question and seems from your point of view, they are different -- they had a very different -- different exception in this case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: From your point of view, you're asking us to pursuit Justice Brennan's question to say that -- that those conditions which in your -- from your point of view would make this a valid statute, namely, that there was some type, some domiciliary type between this woman in New York, that was the precondition of the obligation and you say the New York Court of Appeals didn't -- was not warranted in the facts to make such a finding, it did make such a finding and we must overrule that finding as a matter of constitutional law, is that it?

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: That's it.

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: Well now, may I pursue that a second with you, sir?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Suppose he'd moved out to Nevada a month earlier and had obtained his divorce a week or two before this New York statute became effective?

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: Well, then we would have a question of conflict of laws as to whether or not the applicable law in existence at the time the divorce decree is rendered would fix the wife's rights at that particular time.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: However, there was a conflict in the forces here because on the one hand we're dealing with jurisdictional power, the jurisdictional power of the Nevada court to extend its judgment beyond its borders against non-residents and adjudicate upon that personal right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, that's why I don't quite understand why you answered Justice Harlan that it might depend in the New Mexico case that should been a domiciliary of New Mexico on New Mexico's law at the time of the divorce.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What difference does it make on -- as I understand your argument, basically it is that based on Estin, Armstrong, Pennoyer and Neff, Nevada could not in anywise by its decree affect personal rights.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: That's right, sir.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: I'm trying to agree with Your Honor in principle.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: I do not disagree with it.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: I'm just saying that possibly that may be an argument -- now, I'm not prepared to sustain that argument here.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: This is all a question of whether a State have, as Justice Brennan indicated a minute ago, a State may by virtue of the fact that it affect citizens of its own, domiciliaries of its own, may provide that the ex-husband should maintain the ex-wife.

context.speaker: Monroe J. Winsten
context.text: That is --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That -- that's what you ultimately have to rest on?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Voice Overlap) Forget all about misconduct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The whole basis of Judge Fuld's opinion on which you are relying is that alimony isn't just a personal obligation like a man suing on a debt, on a note.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The view of Judge Fuld is that it isn't -- that alimony is an incident to the status and thereby do not see how you can escape.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In fairly answering Justice Black's question that in as much as Nevada can cutoff alimony, Nevada can impose alimony in favor of New York to be respected in other State.

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: Are you -- may it please you.

context.speaker: Sol A. Rosenblatt
context.text: Judge Black asked me my personal opinion.

Webb v. Illinois Central Railroad Compan.speaker: Justice Warren
Webb v. Illinois Central Railroad Compan.case_name: Webb v. Illinois Central Railroad Company
Webb v. Illinois Central Railroad Compan.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1956

context.speaker: Herbert J. Deany
context.text: The answer to that is --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Does the record show that it was not screened?

context.speaker: Herbert J. Deany
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, that's correct.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, I -- I thought you will answer to Justice Reed that it didn't show that it was screened.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But on the contrary, it shows it was not screened, isn't that right?

context.speaker: Herbert J. Deany
context.text: The answer to the question at that time, it was not screened at that time.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Robinson
context.text: Pardon, sir?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: An exclusive jurisdiction that may be waived is something else than an exclusive jurisdiction period.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Robinson
context.text: Well, the -- the waiver raised an entirely different issue whether or not the part respecting in waiver is legal or constitutional.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, that -- that's the subject to which I think that Justice Black in part of it asked you to address yourself.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All I'm suggesting is it is not correct to say that if one is restricted to the Administrative Agreement that if the United States exclusive jurisdiction --

context.speaker: Joseph S. Robinson
context.text: I'm -- I don't --

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Now, this Court has said in a number of cases that international law is not merely what the writers may say it ought to be, but its not -- and it's what the law is, what you can find from the decisions and also what the practice it is amongst the nations of the world and that's how this Court determines what international law is and it doesn't make any difference on how much you theorize about what immunity you have from the law -- criminal law of another country if you can't persuade that country that that is the law.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: You aren't going to get very far with that kind of a theory.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I -- I interrupted you when you started to tell the Court what the -- what the rulings were if you permit me to say so and you agreed that one thing they all agreed on was Chief Justice Marshall's opinion with which the Chief Justice read before lunch and they all agreed that there's an implied consent ahead.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We have not.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: No.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Did --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Solicitor, could you -- if I may carry on the Chief Justice's and Justice Brennan's questions.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Would it be possible between now and the time this argument closes to have had from the Department of Defense instances that specifically answer the questions put to you.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Namely, whether charges of major crimes by Canadians, where they're restricted to that, by Canadians stationed on our soil whether in such a case the question has arisen in which we saw or some State, this could normally be a state prosecution, what's -- in which some State of the Union asserted its local jurisdiction and Canada invoked her interest under the Treaty to have the alleged conflict turned over to its authorities, could that be done?

context.speaker: Joseph S. Robinson
context.text: And for your information, Your Honor, in this Canadian brief when they told the Canadian high court that there was absolute immunity from jurisdiction of the local Government over the foreign forces, they cite as their first authority for that proposition, the Schooner Exchange case.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Robinson
context.text: And now they're cited for the other proposition.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: How do you dispose of this language in the Schooner Exchange case as I -- I see it cited on -- or quoted on page 23 of the Government's brief.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: This language of Chief Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The jurisdiction of courts is a branch to that which is possessed by the nation as an independent sovereign power.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The jurisdiction of the nation within its own territory is necessarily exclusive and absolute.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense decided that this determination should be carried out.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The President confirmed their joint conclusion.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: A sovereign nation has exclusive jurisdiction to punish offenses against its laws committed within its borders, unless it expressly or impliedly consents to surrender its jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Based is on the authority of Schooner Exchange versus M'Faddon in 7 Cranch 116, in an opinion written by Chief Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Japan's cession to the United States of jurisdiction to try military personnel for conduct constituting an offense against the laws of both countries was conditioned by the covenant of Article XVII, Section 3, paragraph (c) of the Protocol to the effect that the authorities of the State having the primary right shall give sympathetic consideration to a request from the authorities of the other State for a waiver of its right in cases where the other State considers such waiver to be of particular importance.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The issue for our decision is therefore narrowed to the question whether, upon the record before us, the Constitution or legislation subsequent to the Security Treaty prohibited the carrying out of this provision authorized by the Treaty for waiver of the qualified jurisdiction granted by Japan.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: We find no constitutional or statutory -- statutory barrier to the provision as applied here.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: In the absence of such encroachment, the wisdom of the arrangement is exclusively for the determination of the Executive and Legislative Branches.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The judgment of the District Court in No. 1103 is reversed, and its judgment in No. 1108 is affirmed.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: The mandates are directed to issue forthwith.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And were the overt acts -- anything more than the advocacy that you're speaking?

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: What was the nature of the overt act?

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: The overt acts --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I'm just following up, Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question.

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: Where a -- in the nature of attendance at Communist Party meetings, Lenin Memorial rallies, etcetera.

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: And by two, willfully and knowingly organizing and helping to organize as the Communist Party of the United States of America, a society group and assembly of persons who teach and advocate the overthrow and destruction of the Government of the United States by force and violence with the same intent.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But the point is that as you read, excluding in a cloud of uncertainty that advocate there means is to advocate in order to fill the minds with different ideas.

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: The judges charged and didn't leave any doubt about that.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Your (Voice Overlap) Mr. Justice Black --

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: And I don't think that there is any doubt in the indictment either but the important thing is that the charge didn't leave any in doubt.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I thought you -- you talked of the hypothetical case put to you by Justice Black, would be centered by requirements of the statute because it didn't -- the case put by my brother Black wasn't the case of urging (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: The judges charged and didn't leave any doubt about that.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Your (Voice Overlap) Mr. Justice Black --

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: And I don't think that there is any doubt in the indictment either but the important thing is that the charge didn't leave any in doubt.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I thought you -- you talked of the hypothetical case put to you by Justice Black, would be centered by requirements of the statute because it didn't -- the case put by my brother Black wasn't the case of urging (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Philip R. Monahan
context.text: As I understood Mr. Justice Black's --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- that indictment -- I didn't hear the word "urging" was in there, was it?
